metadata.title: Nanomaterials and Technologies for Lithium-Ion Hybrid Supercapacitors

sections.text: cathode materials are required to possess high capacitance to match with LIB-type anodes. Meanwhile, pre-lithiation proves an effective strategy to achieve high cell voltages and high energy density accordingly. In this review we first summarize the requirement on electrode materials for LIHSs, and then propose two levels of LIHSs with the clarification of true LIHSs according to the energy and power density. Finally, we give an outlook for future LIHSs.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Energy and environment are severe problems in the current society. In recent years, the booming development of electric vehicles (EVs) is expected to reduce gasoline consumption and pollutant discharge.[1–5] However, there are still technological barriers for EVs, especially electrical energy storage.[6, 7] Currently, the commonly used electrochemical devices in EVs are lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and supercapacitors. LIBs deliver higher energy density but lower power density, while supercapacitors provide higher power density and longer cycle life but lower energy density.[1–3, 8–11] Thus, new electrochemical storage devices with both high energy and power density are urgently needed. The recently emerging lithium-ion hybrid supercapacitors (LIHSs), also known as lithium-ion hybrid electrochemical capacitors or lithium-ion capacitors (LICs), are one of the promising candidates to bridge the gap between LIBs and supercapacitors.[12–16]
As shown in Figure 1, a LIHS consists of an intercalation LIBtype anode and a capacitor-type cathode with a nonaqueous electrolyte containing lithium salts.[1, 3, 9] As we know, LIBs are called “rocking chair batteries”[17] since lithium ions move reversibly between two electrodes when cycling. However, in LIHSs, the anions (such as PF6
) adsorb/desorb on the surface of capacitor-type cathodes, while pseudocapacitive reactions occur to LIB-type anodes with lithium ion intercalation/de-intercalation.[3, 18–20] Capacitor-type cathodes are commonly electric double layer carbonaceous materials such as activated carbon (AC) and graphene, while LIB-type anodes are usually the insertion-type electrode materials including transition
metal oxides, phosphates and graphite.[9] There are also reports on so-called LIHSs containing capacitor-type anodes and conventional LIB cathodes, such as LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4, [21, 22] LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2, [23] LiFePO4, [24–26] and LiMn2O4. [27–29] However, these devices suffer from lower cell voltages due to the limited operating potential windows of the electrodes in such a configuration.[30] Moreover, most of them exhibit the behaviors of LIBs, including bending charge–discharge curves (Figure 2 a),[21, 22, 25, 26, 28, 29] redox peaks in cyclic voltammetric (CV)
This manuscript is part of a Special Issue on Nanomaterials for Energy Conversion and Storage. A link to the Table of Contents will appear here once the Special Issue is assembled.
ChemNanoMat 2016, 00, 0 – 0 www.chemnanomat.org 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim2&&
These are not the final page numbers!
tests (Figure 2 b),[26] and a mechanism of lithium ions reacting with the cathode.[23, 27]
A LIB works through lithium ions intercalating/de-intercalating into/from the bulk of materials. However, the sluggish diffusion kinetics in the bulk affects the fast redox reaction, and is the obstacle to deliver high power density,[9, 31, 32] which makes it unsuitable to match with the high power capacitortype cathode. Many groups have demonstrated that nanoparticles with ultra-small sizes (<10 nm) display pseudocapacitive performances, and the diffusion limitations are solved and most redox reactions are restricted to or near the surface.[8, 33–35] Nanoparticles with sub-10 nm diameters exhibit an optimal response to rapid redox reactions with the advantages of larger external surface area and shorter ion diffusion length. Thus, ultra-small materials are one of the key points for LIHSs.
Moreover, the capacitance match between capacitor-type cathodes and LIB-type anodes is another key point for LIHSs. The conventional capacitor-type cathodes (such as AC) in electric double layer supercapacitors suffer from the low capacitance[16, 36] which makes them unable to match with LIB-type anodes in LIHSs. The capacitance of capacitor-type cathodes can be improved by enlarging the specific surface area of materials.[20, 37–42] In this regard, cathodes with nanoporous architectures are highly required. Also, heteroatom doping to electric double layer carbonaceous nanomaterials proves an effective method for improving the electrical conductivity and offering more additional defects as ion storage sites.[8, 20, 43–48]
As mentioned above, high energy and power density are the main features of LIHSs. The energy density (E, Wh kg 1) and power density (P, W kg 1) can be expressed in the following equations:[3, 11, 15, 20, 27, 40, 42, 49, 50]
E ¼ 0:5 CV 2 ð1Þ
P ¼ 0:25 V2=R ð2Þ
where C (F kg 1) is the specific capacitance of the full cell, V (V) is the cell’s operating voltage and R (W) represents equivalent series resistance (ESR). From Equations (1) and (2), both power and energy density are proportional to the square of the operating voltage V2 and the energy density can be augmented by increasing the specific capacitance C. Therefore, in order to achieve high energy and power density, LIHSs should have the ability to deliver larger capacitance and work at higher voltages.
High voltages are possible when capacitor-type cathodes work at a higher potential, while LIB-type anodes work at a lower potential. Pre-lithiation is a good strategy to lower the potential of anodes, even as low as that of lithium metal.[4, 8, 9] However, pre-lithiation process and lithiation degree greatly affect the cycle performance and the self-discharge of the anodes by the formation of solid electrolyte interface (SEI) films.[30] Thus, pre-lithiation also plays an important role in high-performance LIHSs.
It is necessary to identify whether those devices involving electrode reactions between lithium ions and active materials or only lithium ion adsorption are true LIHSs or not. Hence,
true LIHSs should be defined strictly. Since the LIHS is a kind of supercapacitor, it must display the characteristics of nearly straight charge–discharge curves (Figure 2 c), nearly rectanglelike CV curves without pronounced redox peaks (Figure 2 d) and an approximately linear relationship between the peak current and the scanning rate from CV curves.[31, 32] LIHSs were proposed to improve the energy density to the LIB level, while maintaining the power density at the supercapacitor level or even higher. According to Equations (1) and (2), a high voltage is necessary for higher energy and power density. Thus, nonaqueous electrolytes should be used in favor of high voltages and subsequently high energy density. If “LIHSs” with aqueous electrolytes or supercapacitors containing lithium ions/lithium compounds cannot work at higher voltages and achieve larger energy density than conventional supercapacitors, they are not regarded as true LIHSs in this review. Moreover, long cycle life is also required for true LIHSs.
Haichen Gu was born in Tianjin, China in 1988. He received his B.S. in 2011 and M.S. in 2014 with the guidance of Prof. Xiuqin Ou, both majoring in Materials Science and Engineering from Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin, China. In 2015, he joined Prof. Zhen Zhou’s group in Nankai University for PhD study. His research interest is the design and preparation of nanomaterials for sodium ion batteries and hybrid supercapacitors.
Jinping Wei was born in Jiangxi, China in 1965. He received B.S. in 1987, majoring in Chemistry from Xiamen University, China. After three years of educational work, he came to Nankai University for further study and received his M.S. in 1993 and PhD in 2003. In 2005, he worked in Monash University, Australia as a visiting scholar. Since 1993, he has been working in the Institute of New Energy Material Chemistry, Nankai University as an associate professor. His research interest focuses on materials for lithium and sodium ion batteries.
Zhen Zhou was born in Shandong, China in 1971. After he received his B.S. in 1994 and PhD in 1999 at Nankai University, China, he joined the faculty in 1999. Two years later, he began to work at Nagoya University, Japan as a JSPS postdoctoral fellow. In 2005, he returned to Nankai University as an associate professor. In 2011, he was promoted as a full professor. He is now the Director of Institue of New Energy Material Chemistry, Nankai University. His main research interest is design, preparation and application of advanced materials for energy storage and conversion.
ChemNanoMat 2016, 00, 0 – 0 www.chemnanomat.org 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim3 &&
These are not the final page numbers!
A true LIHS should be fabricated with LIB-type anode materials with diameters below 10 nm and modified high-capacitance capacitor-type cathode materials with high specific surface area and high electrical conductivity. In addition, pre-lithiation is necessary for high voltages and affects the capacitance decay and self-discharge after cycles.[30, 51] In this review, we will summarize the above three points for true LIHSs: ultrasmall LIB-type anodes, capacitor-type cathodes with high capacitance, and pre-lithiation for anodes. Also, the further improvement of LIHSs will be discussed. Finally, we will give an outlook for the future development of LIHSs.

sections.heading: 2. Ultra-Small LIB-Type Anode Materials
sections.text:
In a LIB bulk electrode, lithium ions intercalate/deintercalate when charging and discharging. The sluggish lithium ion diffusion kinetics would hinder the power density of LIHSs.[31, 52, 53] When LIB-type anode materials are prepared on the nanoscale, the power density will be improved due to the shorter distance for ion and electron transportation. However, the increase of power density alone does not indicate a transformation from LIB-type electrodes to capacitor-type electrodes, because of the faradic CV peaks and the battery-like non-linear galvanostatic profiles. If the particles are reduced to be smaller than 10 nm, LIB-type anode materials would display capacitorlike performance.[31–33, 54–56] The phenomenon of LIB-type anode materials with sizes around 10 nm showing capacitor-like behavior was first introduced by Okubo and co-workers.[33] They prepared bulk and nanoscale LiCoO2 particles with various crystalline sizes and discussed the size effect on electrochemical behaviors. From Figure 3, the discharge curves become increasingly straight and the plateaus gradually shrink with decreasing the crystallite size. In other words, the capacitor behavior becomes increasingly prominent as the crystallite size is reduced from bulk to nanoscale (6 nm). For a bulk material, the site energy of inner intercalated lithium ions is a constant
ChemNanoMat 2016, 00, 0 – 0 www.chemnanomat.org 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim4&&
These are not the final page numbers!
e, while those of the surface-intercalated lithium ions vary, but are all higher than e in a certain range. When the particles are reduced to nanoscale, the specific surface area will become larger, which means that there are more surface lithium ions with higher site energy. The higher site energy facilitates the intercalation of lithium ions on or near the surface.
Other investigations confirmed the result that ultra-small nanoparticles lead to capacitor-like performances. Kim et al.[34] prepared TiO2/reduced graphene oxide (RGO) composites. The average particle size of the ultra-small TiO2 was reduced to 6.2 nm. Besides the improvement of the electrical conductivity of TiO2, the utilization of RGO also led to the formation of even smaller TiO2 nanoparticles due to heterogeneous nucleation sites provided by the defects in the surface of RGO. Because of the faster heterogeneous nucleation, the growth of particles was comparatively suppressed and, subsequently ultra-small
nanocrystalline TiO2 particles formed. The fabricated LIHS was composed of TiO2/RGO//AC with LiPF6 as the lithium source. It cycled at 1–3 V and an energy density of 42 Wh kg 1 was achieved at 800 W kg 1. The authors also compared the electrochemical performance of three kinds of nanocrystalline TiO2 particles with different equivalent particle sizes: TiO2/RGO: 6.2 nm (Figure 4 a); TiO2 without RGO: 10 nm (Figure 4 b); and commercial TiO2 : 20 nm (Figure 4 c). The smallest nanocrystalline TiO2/RGO exhibited lower charge transfer resistance (Figure 4 d), higher capacitance (Figure 4 e) and higher energy density than those of the other two samples with bigger particle sizes at the same power density.
Yang et al.[8] prepared MnO-loaded graphene nanosheets (MnO@GNS) via a hydrothermal route. The MnO nanoparticles were 5 nm in diameter (Figure 5 a and 5 b) which was beneficial for the surface pseudocapacitance reaction between lithium ions and active materials. The MnO@GNS composite with a crumpled 3D architecture showed a high specific surface area of 162.6 m2 g 1. As shown in Figure 5 c and 5 d, the half-cell of MnO@GNS//Li exhibited CV curves with only little polarization and a linear relationship be-
tween the scanning rate and peak current. Hence, 3D nano MnO@GNS showed capacitor-like characteristics, even at a larger scanning rate, due to the sub-10 nm ultra-small MnO nanoparticles, and the advantages of high specific surface area and conductive carbon nanomaterials.
Naoi et al.[35] checked ultra-small nanocrystalline Li4Ti5O12 (ncLi4Ti5O12) with a particle size range of 5–20 nm, shown in Figure 6 a and 6 b. The nc-Li4Ti5O12/CNF (CNF = carbon nanofiber, shown in Figure 6 c) composite was prepared through a simple sol–gel method under ultra-centrifugal force and subsequent high-temperature annealing. As the optimal weight ratio of ncLi4Ti5O12 and CNF was 70/30. The LIHS of nc-Li4Ti5O12/CNF//AC worked in the voltage range of 1.5–3.0 V with a current density range of 0.18 to ultra-high 26.8 A g 1 (corresponding to 1– 140 C). Figure 6 d shows that the LIHS of nc-Li4Ti5O12/CNF//AC delivered the highest energy density of 40 Wh L 1 (55 Wh kg 1) and the energy density remains at 21 Wh L 1 (28 Wh kg 1) at a higher power density of 7.5 kW L 1 (10 kW kg 1). Besides the establishment of electric paths by CNF, the enhancement of power characteristics of the LIHS of nc-Li4Ti5O12/CNF//AC also resulted from the ultra-small size of Li4Ti5O12.
Besides the above-mentioned TiO2/graphene, MnO/graphene composites and Li4Ti5O12, the composites of graphene and transition metal oxides (MoOx, MnO2, FexOy and V2O5) or sulfide (MoS2) may also be appropriate anode materials for LIHSs.
Ultra-small active materials with diameters of <10 nm show capacitor-like features due to the enhanced exterior surface area which avoids the sluggish ion diffusion in the bulk and subsequently impart the higher capacity and power density.

sections.heading: 3. Capacitor-Type Cathode Materials
sections.text:
Capacitor-type cathodes work as electric double layers or pseudocapacitors. Generally, the utilized capacitor-type cathodes are carbonaceous materials, such as AC, carbon nanotubes and graphene. Due to the only physical adsorption/desorption charge-storage mechanism or fewer pseudocapacitance reactions on the surface,[57] conventional capacitor-type cathodes suffer from lower capacitance.[16, 36] According to Equation (1), the capacitance has strong relationship to the energy density of LIHSs. Thus, it is urgent to improve the capacitance of the capacitor-type cathode. To the best of our knowledge, there are two possible ways to enhance the capacitance. One is the enlargement of the specific surface area, and the other is the utilization of heteroatom (such as N atom)-doped carbonaceous materials. Both can increase the ion storage sites on the surface of the capacitor-type cathode.[43, 58]
Sennu et al.[59] utilized tube-like AC as the capacitor-type cathode and Li4Ti5O12 as the LIB-type anode to fabricate the LIHS. They investigated the relationship between the specific surface area of the AC electric double layer cathode and the electrochemical performance. The surface area of KC01-800, KC11-800, KC21-800 and KC21-900 are 455, 1334, 1589 and 2410 m2 g 1, respectively. The sample KC21-900 with the highest surface area showed the optimal capacitance of 140 F g 1 with only 9 % capacitance fading after 5000 cycles in the symmetric supercapacitor. The LIHS of KC21-900//Li4Ti5O12 worked at the voltage range of 1–3 V and delivered the optimal specific energy density of 80, 70, 55, 50, 40 and 20 Wh kg 1 at specific power density of 0.2, 0.4, 1, 2, 3 and 4 kW kg 1, respectively.
Gokhale el al.[37] showed the positive effect of both heteroatom doping and specific surface area enlargement on the electric double layer ODC (oligomer-derived carbon) cathode. N
Figure 6. Morphology (a) overview and (b) magnified view of nc-Li4Ti5O12/CNF composites. (c) HRTEM image of pristine CNF. (d) Ragone plots of the symmetric capacitor (AC//AC) and LIHS (nc-Li4Ti5O12/CNF//AC) with different weight ratios of Li4Ti5O12 and CNF. Figure reproduced with permission from [35].
ChemNanoMat 2016, 00, 0 – 0 www.chemnanomat.org 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim6&&
These are not the final page numbers!
doping enhanced the electrical conductivity and high rate performance of the ODC cathode and simultaneously improved the energy density of the LIHS. The high specific surface area (1381 m2 g 1) results from the highly porous architecture of the ODC which makes it suitable to be applied as the capacitortype cathode in LIHSs. The highest-concentration pores are ultra-micropores with a diameter of 1–2 nm. Such micropores provide much more adsorption sites for the ions. Other larger micropores with diameters of 2–6 nm benefit the transportation of ions. A small amount of pores larger than 10 nm mainly contribute to saving the electrolyte. The LIHS was fabricated with ODC as the capacitor-type cathode, Li4Ti5O12 as the LIBtype anode, and LiPF6 in the electrolyte. The ODC//Li4Ti5O12 LIHS showed the highest energy density of 63 Wh kg 1 at the power density of 200 W kg 1 when cycled at 1–3 V.
Yang et al.[8] synthesized porous 3D hierarchical N-doped carbon (HNC) nanosheets as the capacitor-type cathode. HNC showed graphitic features in the sp2 domain and a specific surface area of 991.6 m2 g 1. The heteroatom N doping and graphitic features further improved the electrical conductivity and increased the charge storage sites. HNC showed a capacitance twice of that of commercial AC and higher capacitance retention. 3D architecture carbonaceous cathode materials were also suggested by other groups.[38]
The Huang group[38] used graphene for both the cathode and anode of LIHSs. The graphene capacitor-type cathode PF16 was prepared by adding phenol and formaldehyde and showed an ultra-high specific surface area of 3523 m2 g 1, which resulted from not only extremely curved single-layered graphene sheets with well-controlled pore sizes of 1–7 nm, but also the 3D architecture of graphene (Figure 7 a–c). Similar to other groups, they also indicated that the pores provide better accessibility and more effective specific surface area (adsorption sites) for the ions in the electrolyte. Another superiority of PF16 for the application as capacitor-type cathodes is its high electrical conductivity of 303 S m 1. In addition, the authors also revealed that the mass ratio between the capacitor-type
cathode and the LIB-type anode was an important factor for the energy and power density of LIHSs and, as shown in Figure 7 d and 7 e, the optimal mass ratio may not be a constant value with various current densities. The change of the best mass ratio at different current densities was attributed to the different rate performances of PF16 and flash pre-lithiated reduced graphene oxide (FRGO) as well as the actual electrochemical potential window compared with the designed one for each electrode, which would affect the actual specific capacity of the electrodes. The LIHS was composed of PF16 as the cathode and FRGO as the LIB-type anode, and exhibited the energy density of 148.3–71.5 Wh kg 1 with the power density of 141–7800 W kg 1 simultaneously in the voltage range of 0–4.2 V.
The appropriate capacitor-type cathode materials with high specific capacitance and electrical conductivity could be 3D hierarchical nanoporous carbon materials doped with N, B, O or P.

sections.heading: 4. Anode Pre-lithiation
sections.text:
As mentioned above, a high voltage is necessary for improving the energy and power density of LIHSs. The high voltage is generated by the configuration of both the high-potential cathode and the low-potential anode. Pre-lithiation is an effective method for keeping the lower potential of anodes, even as low as that of lithium metal. In 2005, Fuji Heavy Industry Ltd.[60] proposed Li ion capacitors with pre-lithiated polyacene as the anode. The cell voltage was elevated from the past 2.5 V to 3.8 V based on the active carbon unit, and the energy density was improved.
Ren et al.[4] fabricated a LIHS composed of AC as the cathode and pre-lithiated graphene nanosheets as the anode. Pre-lithiated graphene nanosheets contributed to a higher voltage range of 2.0–4.0 V. The LIHS delivered a maximum power density of 222.2 W kg 1 at the energy density of 61.7 Wh kg 1. Later, Yang et al.[8] pre-lithiated MnO@GNS anodes and the potential was lowered and kept at 0.45 V vs. Li/Li+ . The LIHS of HNC and pre-lithiated MnO@GNS provided a high operation voltage of 4 V and delivered a high energy density of 127 Wh kg 1 at the power density of 125 W kg 1 and 83.25 Wh kg 1 at even 25 kW kg 1.
Recently, Yu et al.[61] have investigated nitrogen-enriched mesoporous carbon nanosphere/graphene (N-GMCS) cathodes coupled with different anodes including pre-lithiated microcrystalline graphite (PLMG), pre-lithiated flake graphite (PLFG) and Li4Ti5O12 (LTO) without pre-lithiation. Pre-lithiation indeed improved the voltage window. CV (Figure 8 a) and charge–discharge curves (Figure 8 b) indicate that the voltage ranges of N-GMCS//PLMG and N-GMCS//PLFG were both 2.2–4.2 V, while N-GMCS//LTO exhibited a lower voltage range of 1.0–3.0 V. As shown in Figure 8 c, N-GMCS//PLMG provided the optimal electrochemical performance that the highest energy density was 80 Wh kg 1 at the power density of 152 W kg 1. The energy density stayed above 70 Wh kg 1 at the power density range of 152 to 15 000 W kg 1 and the LIHS can still deliver an energy density of 32 Wh kg 1 at an ultrahigh power density of
ChemNanoMat 2016, 00, 0 – 0 www.chemnanomat.org 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim7 &&
These are not the final page numbers!
112 kW kg 1. N-GMCS//PLMG displayed longer cycle life with only 7 % capacitance decay after 4000 cycles.
However, note that the pre-lithiation degree may affect the formation of SEI films, and subsequently the electrochemical performance. Zhang and co-workers[51] investigated the effect of pre-lithiation degree on mesocarbon microbead (MCMB) anodes of LIHSs. As shown in Table 1, the potential of pre-lithiated anodes gradually decreased from 2.1 V to 0.001 V with increasing the lithiation degree up to 94.09 %. However, full lithiation would hamper the improvement of the electrochemical
performances of LIHSs in terms of the capacitance and cycle performance (Figure 9 a). Because the excessive lithium led to more consumption of the electrolyte and formed a thicker SEI film, which increased the resistance of lithium ion diffusion. Figure 9 b shows that the lithiation degree of 80 % exhibited the highest energy density of 92.3 Wh kg 1, power density of 5.5 kW kg 1 and capacity retention of 97 % after 1000 cycles at the voltage range of 2.0–4.0 V and the discharge rate of 2 C.
The SEI film has a close relationship with lithium consumption and the electrochemical performance. A poorly formed SEI film may result in unwanted electrochemical reactions by direct contact between graphite and electrolytes. Sivakkumar et al.[30] reported that the pre-lithiation process would affect
Figure 8. (a) CV and (b) charge–discharge curves of N-GMCS//PLMG, N-GMCS//PLFG and N-GMCS//LTO. (c) Ragone plot and cycle performance of N-GMCS// PLMG. Figure reproduced with permission from [61].

ChemNanoMat 2016, 00, 0 – 0 www.chemnanomat.org 2016 Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim8&&
These are not the final page numbers!
the formation of SEI films. Thus, the lithiation method plays an important role in the stability of the pre-lithiated anode. Their studies indicated that the direct short circuiting lithium with graphite or graphite only electrochemically lithiated at a low current (0.05 C) cannot efficiently prevent the self-discharge of pre-lithiated graphite anodes. Another method is externally short circuiting graphite with lithium electrode via a resistor. The initial voltage was set to 1.0 V and the current sloped down with time from 0.05 C until the voltage reached 0.05 V. The pre-lithiated graphite electrode exhibited a slower self-discharge rate compared with the electrodes obtained through the other two methods, but the lithiation took nearly 11 days which is much longer than the other two methods. Kim et al.[62] reported that the coulombic efficiency of LIHSs was also affected by pre-lithiation. Pre-lithiation by the internal short process is better than through the electrochemical process and external short circuit process in terms of improving the coulombic efficiency, because the anodes that were prelithiated through the latter two processes suffered from a shortage of intercalated lithium.
Pre-lithiation results in a lower anode potential, and a higher voltage and energy density of the cell. The cycle stability is greatly affected by the self-discharge of anodes which is correlated with the formation of SEI films. The uniformity and thickness of SEI films is highly affected by the pre-lithiation process and degree. Therefore, appropriate pre-lithiation degrees and suitable methods will lead to optimal electrochemical performances.

sections.heading: 5. Summary and Perspective
sections.text:
In the recent decade, LIHSs have been intensively studied in terms of high energy and power density as well as long cycle life. According to the energy and power density, LIHSs can be classified into two levels. One is the ordinary level LIHS, which generally consists of an electric double layer cathode and a LIB-type anode without pre-lithiation, such as the wellknown Li4Ti5O12//AC LIHS. This kind of LIHSs, first proposed by Amatucci et al.[63] in 2001, generally work in the voltage window of 1–3 V and deliver higher energy and power density than conventional supercapacitors (* in Figure 10).[34, 35, 37, 59] Nevertheless, some reported ordinary-level LIHSs did not show better electrochemical performance including energy density, power density and cycle life to meet the standard for bridging the gap between LIBs and conventional supercapacitors in terms of the energy and power density ( in Figure 10).[64] The other kind is the high-level LIHS, which consists of a higher-capacitance electric double layer cathode and a pre-lithiated LIBtype anode. The high-level LIHS was first proposed by Fuji Heavy Industry Ltd. in 2005.[60] Pre-lithiation effectively lowers the potential of the anode even as low as lithium metal and increases the voltage range to 0–4 V. The energy and power density are enhanced prominently (~ in Figure 10)[4, 8, 38, 51, 61] compared with the ordinary level LIHS. Ultra-small nanoparticles of around 10 nm efficiently improve the power density of the LIB-type anode by confining the lithium ions onto the surface of the nanoparticles and
avoiding the sluggish kinetics for lithium ion diffusion in the bulk. In addition, the capacitor-type cathode with high capacitance is suitable to match with the LIB-type anode. The high capacitance of cathodes can be obtained by increasing the specific surface area and improving the electrical conductivity. Thus, recently, heteroatom-doped 3D hierarchical porous carbon materials have attracted much attention. For fabricating the ordinary-level LIHSs, both ultra-small anode materials and high-capacitance cathode materials should be considered. However, the above two factors are not enough for high-level LIHSs with high energy and power density. Pre-lithiation stands out as an effective way to increase both energy and power density. Moreover, the pre-lithiation method greatly affects the cycle stability, self-discharge and coulombic efficiency. Therefore, it is necessary for the anode to be pre-lithiated through a suitable process to an appropriate degree.
With the increasing demand for energy storage devices with both high energy and power density, high-level LIHSs are extremely desired. In order to achieve even higher energy and power density, there are some possible solutions or pathways, such as choosing suitable electrolytes with wide stable electrochemical windows, finding high potential capacitor-type cathodes and adopting high-efficiency pre-lithiation processes to guarantee high operation voltages. Another challenge in highlevel LIHSs is the match between the two electrodes. For the kinetic match, anode materials should be highly nanocrystallized and cathode materials should have higher capacitance and conductivity. For the capacitance match, the mass ratio of two electrodes should be carefully evaluated. Nanomaterials with high specific surface area and electrical conductivity and pre-lithiation technology are vital to achieve high-level or even further upgraded LIHSs. Thus, investigations on such materials and technologies are urgent for high-level and upgraded LIHSs.

REVIEW
Energy Storage
Haichen Gu, Yuan-En Zhu, Jiqian Yang, Jinping Wei,* Zhen Zhou*
&& –&&
Nanomaterials and Technologies for Lithium-Ion Hybrid Supercapacitors True lithium ion hybrid supercapacitors (LIHSs) are composed of ultrasmall and pre-lithiated LIB-type anodes and capacitor-type cathodes with high surface area and electrical conductivity. In this Focus Review, we introduce the concept of LIHSs and summarize their recent progress in detail.

metadata.abstractText: For developing energy storage devices with both high energy and power density, lithium-ion hybrid supercapacitors (LIHSs) are the optimal candidate to bridge the gap between lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and conventional supercapacitors. A LIHS consists of a capacitor-type cathode and a LIB-type anode. However, the particle size of LIB-type anode materials should be within 10 nm to overcome the sluggish ion diffusion in the bulk. In addition, capacitor-type cathode materials are required to possess high capacitance to match with LIB-type anodes. Meanwhile, pre-lithiation proves an effective strategy to achieve high cell voltages and high energy density accordingly. In this review we first summarize the requirement on electrode materials for LIHSs, and then propose two levels of LIHSs with the clarification of true LIHSs according to the energy and power density. Finally, we give an outlook for future LIHSs.
